awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Manufacturable Implementation of Thin Glass for Next Generation Electronics Packaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is that enabling processing thin glass substrates for next generation communications and packaging needs will mean faster communications with improved power efficiency.  Society has an ever-expanding need for data, due to technologies such as mobile communications, cloud computing, the Internet of Things (IoT), and the shift of communication to higher frequencies (1s-10s of GHz).  As the frequency increases, traditional material choices, such as silicon, can experience very high losses and therefore there is increasing interest in using insulating materials, such as glass, to improve power efficiency.  Similarly, as device size is also important, ability to process thin materials is also critical.  Successful completion of this work will enable cost-effective processing of thin glass substrates and enable next generation communication initiatives impacting commercial, military and industrial markets.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is proposed to enable processing thin glass substrates in high volume environments.  There has been substantial interest in using glass for next generation RF and packaging solutions for many years due to its advantageous material properties, and scalability.  Of particular interest is the dielectric properties, which provide low electrical loss solutions relative to incumbent materials such as silicon.  Furthermore, the smoothness, hermetic properties and scalability of glass provides additional advantages over materials such as ceramics and organic laminates.  There has been a lot of progress in establishing processes to form thin glass and make precision through glass vias (TGV), as well as demonstrating advantaged functional performance in a lab environment.  There has been a challenge to establish the ability to scale to high volume for thin glass solutions due to gaps in the supply chain.  This SBIR project will establish a process that enables a carrier solution using a silicon carrier that will allow processing of glass in existing infrastructure making thin glass solutions available to the current well established and capable supply chain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mosaic Microsystems is developing a novel glass bonding technology to enable broad adoption of glass substrates and new heterogeneous integration and packaging solutions within the wireless industry. Mosaic Microsystems has developed a proprietary method of temporarily bonding thin glass wafers to a silicon handle wafer, with the silicon adding rigidity and opacity to ensure compatibility with existing fab robots and position-sensors. Mosaic’s temporary bond is stable to over 400 ⁰C and leaves no residue on the glass after debonding, allowing processing in existing semiconductor fabs, leveraging existing high temperature processes, and requiring only a mechanical debond to yield the thin substrates. By providing a means for thin glass (<200 µm thick) to be handled and processed with standard manufacturing equipment, Mosaic’s innovative technology will catalyze broader use of superior glass substrates as a packaging material and fulfill a critical need for customers throughout the electronics supply chain, including vertically integrated device manufacturers, foundries, companies providing outsourced assembly and testing (OSATs), fabless semiconductor companies, and OEMs. This supports continued performance improvements in electronics, heterogeneous integration in mobile devices, infrastructure for mobile, automotive radar, increased wireless communications bandwidth, and increased data handling while reducing energy consumption in data centers through integrated photonics.

During the NSF Phase I SBIR project, Mosaic has made significant progress on both technical and commercialization fronts. The technical team started as guests in a facility where initially the bonding process had lack of reproducibility due to experimental variations in deposition process parameters, glass types, and post-bonding lamination. The desired bond energy was eventually controlled to within the noise level of the bond energy measurement method. In a similar fashion, once the deposition process was well designed and controlled, a consistent process for samples without blister formation during annealing was identified. This concluded the first stage of Mosaic’s technical development.

The Mosaic team identified 2000 sq. ft. of mixed Class 100 / 1000 clean space, suitable for pilot-scale operations, with an additional 1000 sq. ft. of Class 10000 space. Clean chemistry benches, deposition equipment, bonding and debonding set-ups, and basic analytical equipment were installed and operational by the end of February 2019. As might be expected, establishing the process for correct bond energy and bubble-free interface in a new cleanroom, with new equipment and a variety of input glass types, took significant work. Over the course of 2019, the technical team gained additional insight into the mechanisms involved, developed and implemented further techniques to make the process robust, and reduced the particle-induced defects in between the glass and silicon wafers by addressing the root cause. Yields for bonded wafers, using a defect area of 1.5% as a cutoff, went from approximately 75% to over 95% as a result.

The second technical achievement involved developing a tapered via in the glass that allowed successful copper via fill by electroplating, a crucial step for more advanced via-glass products. Cu-plated glass-bonded-to-silicon pairs were successfully polished in a standard CMP process, and the glass showed no cracking or delamination in extended anneals to 400°C. These are further verifications that Mosaic’s handling solution for thin glass allows drop-in processing.

As a result of these achievements, Mosaic delivered prototype products to multiple customers by both sale and sample, with over 250 wafers shipped, and over $150,000 in revenue in the second half of 2019. Customers gave positive feedback that the Mosaic thin-glass handling worked successfully in their fabs, leading to customer reorders. For investment purposes, Mosaic wrote a commercialization plan and built a pitch deck. Mosaic acquired seed-level investments from two strategic investors, and is in discussion with additional funding sources, including potential customers interested in investing, a venture capital company with deep roots in semiconductor processing, and New York State, who has expressed interest in investing with a match of up to 33% of what was raised in the seed round.
